summary: After learning that a stranger has been accidentally killed near their rural homes, four Oregon boys decide to go see the body. On the way, Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton), Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell), Chris Chambers (River Phoenix) and Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) encounter a mean junk man and a marsh full of leeches, as they also learn more about one another and their very different home lives. Just a lark at first, the boys' adventure evolves into a defining event in their lives.

reviews.content: Stand by Me is proof that a simple ending and a rock-solid end credits music goes a long way. Even worth revisiting is the film's power to capture and resonate without much fuss. It stirs deep within you without being too mushy, makes you laugh without being trying to be funny, and best of all, it awakens a delicious sense of must-have nostalgia.

I am by no means saying that this was a badly made or acted movie, I can appreciate talented writing and acting; this is just my personal opinion. I found it more than anything; depressing and disturbing. A friend described it to me by saying it was "like the goonies" to that I say no, no it's not. It had some same actors and some similar themes, that's it. It was a lot more morbid and desperate. 

The main kid is obsessed with finding this dead body, not for justice or for fame but just because he "needed to see it". It's disturbing the lengths this group go to to find said body, almost dying in the process. It isn't fun or light-hearted (like the goonies) and it just seemed to me like it explored the tragic abuse, trauma, depression or bullying of four young boys. Many people might enjoy this type of film (very emotional, sad, almost desolate in that way) but it's not something I like to watch so I did not enjoy it at all.

It's the kind of film that if you're not ready for it will leave you feeling physically sick and like you've misunderstood or missed something (especially when the upbeat happy music starts playing with the credits). In my opinion you would not be missing anything by not watching this movie.

I'd like to specify that it is not emotional in the way that it would make you cry or empathise, but emotional in the way that you have sympathy for the characters in parts and pure disappointment in the people around them. 

Having only just watched it I am left almost speechless, I don't know how to elaborate. I'm going to have to watch another (preferably upbeat) movie before I sleep tonight. (This disturbed me, and I had no problem sleeping both through and after watching things like Jigsaw on separate occasions)

An engaging, unflinching portrait of the dynamic between a group of newly-teenaged boys who rally together for the most significant event summer in a small town could offer: good old-fashioned adventure. "He doesn't hate you, he just doesn't know you." Still an immensely powerful line. River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton's connection is the true heart of this film. They both struggle with personal demons that deal with how they are being perceived in relation to their respective families by those within and outside those very families. And through sharing their struggle with each other, neither sees their dilemma cleanly resolved or finds answers for how to make the mess go away. They just gain greater understanding--and greater strength--of how to live with it and persevere through it.

The real life story behind River Phoenix makes his character's fate that much more difficult to digest. But as film's namesake plays over the ending credits, we're left with a gentle optimism. A bittersweet one, no doubt. But one that's rejuvenating. Full of life.

As you are well aware, there have been many film adaptations of Stephen King's work.  The adaptations have been on both the big and small screen.  They range from excellent (The original miniseries "The Stand" starring Gary Sinise, Rob Lowe and Molly Ringwald. "The Green Mile".  Both the big and small screen adaptations of "It".) to absolutely horrible ("Graveyard Shift".  Silver Bullet".  "The Lawnmower Man").  However, there is one that stands above all else and that is "Stand By Me".  Based on King's novella "The Body" that was originally published in the 1982 book "Different Seasons", the movie is, I would say, 99% faithful to its source material but there are some inevitable changes (In the novella, the fictional town of Castle Rock is in Maine.  In the movie, it is in Oregon where the movie was filmed.  The novella is set in the summer of 1959, the movie in the summer of 1960.  In the novella, Ace Merrill and his gang exact revenge on the protagonist and his friends and it is brutal.), but those changes do not have a negative effect on the story or the movie as a whole.  I don't think I have seen a movie more perfectly cast as "Stand By Me".  The late River Phoenix was in my opinion the best of the entire cast.  He played the part of Christopher Chambers to perfection.  Why he did not receive an Oscar nomination (Hell, why he did not win!) is inexcusable.  Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman (Easily the best performance of his career.) and Jerry O'Connell (His motion picture debut.) are phenomenal, but Phoenix's performance stood out for me.  Emmy Award winner Kiefer Sutherland was excellent (and even frightening) as rival gang leader John "Ace" Merrill.  An excellent display of his acting talent.  His performance send chills up my spine every time I watch it.  In fact I still think he is going to put his cigarette out in River Phoenix's eye.  The scenes featuring the four lead characters are all very well written and even take dialogue from "The Body" almost verbatim.  They translate very well to the screen.  As you watch the movie you almost forget that you are actually watching a movie, the performances almost seem real which is just another reason why this movie work so well on just about every level.  Director Rob Reiner has a very impressive resume (Though unfortunately "North" is included on that.), but "Stand By Me" is definitely his magnum opus.  More than thirty years after its initial release, "Stand By Me" stands the test of time.  Even if you are not a fan of Stephen King I highly recommend you see this truly excellent movie.  You will not be disappointed.

Stand By Me, the 1986 coming-of-age film, directed by Rob Reiner, and based on the Stephen King short story The Body, is one of my so called 'Perfect Films.' A perfect film to me has all of the elements of a good story: comedy, adventure, horror, suspense, and romance. Yes, this movie does not have romance, but in a way it does: in the sense of being in love with your youth during an adventurous summer.

The film Stand By Me is a timeless one. It's the kind of film that when you see it for the first time, or the 50th time, it gives you that nostalgic feeling of familiarity, that safe feeling of pre-pubescent adventure and care-free outlook.

The actors are great, perfectly cast, and deliver fine performances across the board. Arguably it is an all-star cast: Richard Dreyfuss (narrator), River Phoenix, Jerry O'Connell, Corey Feldman, Will Wheaton, Kiefer Sutherland, and John Cusack to name a few. They all respectively show great range, and are all perfectly cast.

The film takes place in Oregon, during Labor Day weekend of 1959. Like I said before, it is based on Stephen King's The Body, which is in his short story collections Different Seasons (which also has Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption and Apt Pupil so it's awesome). The adult Gordie Lachance (Dreyfuss) narrates the story via flashback while writing a novel. The flashback tells the story about him and his friends embarking on a quest to find the body of a local, missing boy near the town of Castle Rock. Speaking of Castle Rock, the antagonist here is Sutherland's younger Ace Merrill.

While the story unfolds, it is revealed that all of the boys are dealing with their own personal issues, all while helping each other in their own way. Gordie (Wheaton) is still grieving and guilt-ridden over the death of his older brother, Teddy (Feldman) is an abused child desperately in denial of his father's malice, Chris (Phoenix) comes from a broken home, and Vern (O'Connell) is shy and timid, while trying to make his way.

We learn more and more about each individual as they trek on through the Oregon wilderness in order to find the body, but what they are really searching for are themselves. We start to care more about the characters, and one-by-one we begin to relate to them. The 1950's contemporary rock and roll soundtrack really plays into the story too.

The film and story age very well, which can be very tough to do when using a period piece that takes place from another decade. They don't need to rely on special effects and technology, and the dialogue from King's work is carefully chose and respective to that time. The set decorations (see the general store), and costumes, are perfectly chosen.

Stand By Me is brilliantly woven using comedy (watch for the pie-eating contest scene), horror (the boys' imaginations in the forest), drama, suspense, and adventure. It's reportedly one of the few film adaptations of his works that Stephen King likes, and I think they got it right too.

It's ironic that the two best filmed adaptations from legendary horror author Stephen King are both dramas (this film and "The Shawshank Redemption" from 1994). After surreptitiously overhearing the location of a dead body, four adolescents in the late Fifties take a two-day trek down the train tracks to find it and become heroes. Along the way, they all experience their own painful maturation processes, learning important lessons about themselves and about life in general.

I didn't grow up in the late Fifties, but I can still appreciate the camaraderie displayed by the four lead actors. Every generation has its own trials and tribulations and yet, as unique as we feel they are, they are universally felt. We are not as alone in our experiences as we think. There's something inherently comforting about that notion. As for this particular group of youngsters, each one has their own well-defined persona that never falls into a stereotype of juvenescence. River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton show more honest emotion in their performances than many veteran actors would ever be able to muster.

There's some genuine humor scattered about, notably in the form of a junkyard dog named Chopper and in the tale of a vengeful overweight teenager Gordie tells his compatriots around a campfire one evening. Dramatic tension is equally represented during a frightful race across a train trestle and a stressful confrontation with the town bullies over who gets to lay claim to the body of Ray Brower. The inclusion of Richard Dreyfuss's narration is a perfect topper to a magnificent work of art. The film's final denouement is one of the saddest, most insightful pieces of philosophy you're ever likely to come across in cinema. I've never seen a better coming of age story on the silver screen than "Stand by Me" . . . and I feel it's highly unlikely I ever will.

Stand by Me (1986) is a coming of age drama focused in on childhood nostalgia for the good old days of hanging out with your best friends. Rob Reiner directed his finest film with Stand by Me. Reiner recreates the 1950's with the clothing, music, town setting, natural surroundings, and the open journey adventure these children undertake. His long panning shots down winding train tracks and forest paths are as gorgeous as the sun sets and warm feelings of yesterday. 

As much as it is a suspense film based off of Stephen King's novella The Body, it takes a hard look at parents' cruelty and neglect in the 1950s while King demonstrates the harsh bullying and lazy days of waiting around for something fun to happen. Stand by Me is a triumph of realism in kids playing together. They eat, joke, swear, and go on adventures in the gorgeous natural surrounding all while mourning lost ones, building new friendships, strengthening old friendships, telling stories, and dreaming of the future.

Stand by Me features an all star cast of excellent child actors. From the dejected, shy authorial type Will Wheaton to chubby goofball Jerry O'Connell. Also, Corey Feldman is the wildly funny and outgoing adrenaline freak with a damaged past. Lastly, the late River Phoenix stars as the tough guy with a heart of gold and kind empathy. I miss Phoenix as an actor for his depth and realism as much as his pained eyes convey even more hurt already. You could already tell he would be the next era of acting after Stand by Me. All these kids were just so believable and likable in Stand by Me.

I must mention Stand by Me also has Kiefer Sutherland as the mean bully with a death wish. His presence is always felt as he exudes menace from the first time we see him. John Cusack and Richard Dreyfuss have nicely understated cameo supporting roles too.

I highly recommend Stand by Me to all audiences that are teenagers and older. It is filled with great humor that is easy to laugh along with, while the drama that comes with getting older should relate to anyone.

Stand by me is an astonishing film based on the novella " the body" by Stephen King. This movie is about these four best friends : Gordie Lachance, Chris Chamber, Vern Tessio and Teddy Duchamp who go on this thrilling adventure to find the body of a dead boy, Ray Brower.

Each of these young 12-13 years old boys have an interesting story: Gordie (main character) lived with his mother,father and brother. Sadly, his brother Denny passed away and Gordie felt like he wasn't really paid any attention to. Chris (the leader of their "Gang"), has a father that drinks too much and a brother, Eyeball Chambers, who is also leader of another gang and a bully. 
Chris is kind of on his own as well. Vern lives with his brother, Billy Tessio who is another bully (in eyeball's gang) and his parents. Then, there is Teddy Duchamp, he has a burnt ear because his dad was an alcoholic who had anger issues and put his ear on the stove.

Honestly, I have some few things I don't really like about the film. For me, the ending was kind of sad... I wish I could change it to make it happier. Then there is a part in the movie that involves a certain animal, which I find disturbing. Expect for these two facts, there isn't more that I dislike about the movie.

Now, one of the things I liked about the movie is that it's well structured ; at the beginning, they are not really grown up, goofing around with each other... and at the end, they overcame dangerous and daring obstacles which made them more mature and they stood up for each other. Next, there is the basic idea of the story (which is all based on finding the body), I really like adventure films, action films but, it's also a comedy film because it contains some funny parts. Also, I really like the characters. Gordie is my favourite because he's full of surprises and unexpected. I can't say more or I will reveal spoilers.

My favourite part in the movie would be around the middle of the film. They face a great danger containing a vehicle in very ,very high place. It just keeps you guessing : will they get out of it? What's going to happen? And it makes you feel like you're there just witnessing the scene waiting for something to just happen. What's good is that we feel as if we struggle with the boys as they grow older (mentally).

Stand by me is probably a film appropriate for young teenagers looking for adventures, action and comedy. By reading the description, you might think that only younger children will appreciate this film but that's not true at all : this film deals with the hard times of change, self acceptance and obviously, friendship. I think that for younger audiences, it would be hard for them to understand the complexity of these themes. And adults would like this film too, it might remind them of their childhood, the adventures they went on as kids.

Moving on, Stand by me is a film with a lot of imagery : there is the narrator's voice during the film, sometimes he talks while describing something like : the weather, how they felt, their surroundings... if we close our eyes, we can imagine the scene, we don't even have to look at what's happening since it's so well described. Besides imagery, You can't really find much of figurative language since it is a film.

Now I can relate to the film in certain ways. When I was younger, I was goofing around lot with my friends (I still do but less) but in a different way. Some scenes of this film made me remember some times I had with my friends that I don't usually think about. 

In conclusion, I think this is a pretty good film that I recommend to a lot of people. It's funny and shows phases of growing up that we can discover. I give it a rating of  ????????/5  because, as I said in the 3rd paragraph, the ending isn't really great and I am not a fan of a certain scene.

There's an atmosphere, an emotion, a feeling to this movie that is perhaps greater than the story itself. The plot is fairly straightforward really -  a group of twelve-year-old kids walk 20 miles along a train track to find a rumoured dead body in the woods. Nothing massively dramatic really happens along the way if the truth be told. They take a pit-stop in a junkyard, a train comes when they're crossing a bridge, and they get some leeches on them passing through a swamp. But that's not really where the legend of this movie comes from, I don't think. 

The lasting appeal of this movie comes from the nostalgia that it evokes of a very specific and melancholic time of life. The time between youth and adulthood, when innocence is dying and the harsh realities of life are breaking in. It's one everyone can relate to. 

There's some clever metaphors that help establish the coming-of-age tone too. The kids start their journey in a hot, summer haze, representing the halcyon, care-free days of youth. By the end of the movie, the summer is ending and the kids are going their separate ways. When they find the body, the sun has gone down and there looks like there's a chill in the air. The long journey itself with death at the end is a metaphor for life itself. 

Normally I hate movies that end on a note of melancholy. If I'd written it, the four of them would have remained friends for life and (spoiler alert), we'd never have discovered that Chris died young. Having said that, if I'd written the story I'd have drastically reduced the profanity and improved their general behaviour too. It's actually quite hard to like the group at first, especially Teddy. They're mouthy, rebellious brats. I wouldn't say I loved them by the end either, but I could at least have some sympathy for why they were all so messed up. 

But melancholy is indeed how it ends. And that's the feeling that stays with you. And I think it stays with you because within us all there's a little bit of sadness for our lost childhood innocence. This movie just taps into that feeling.

"I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve," The Writer (Richard Dreyfuss) reflects at the end of "Stand By Me." "Jesus, does anyone?" A story of male bonding that dances to the beat of adolescence, nostalgia, and the 1950s, it is a coming-of-age film of acuity and acceptably genial sentimentality, as oftentimes funny as it is soul-baring.  Adapted from the novella of the same name by Stephen King, "Stand By Me" is an uncommonly wise genre film aching with a bittersweetness that manages to get to you without being coy about it. 
	Set in 1959 over Labor Day weekend, the film stars Wil Wheaton as Gordie Lachance, a vulnerable preteen whose family life has been dramatically deterred by the tragic death of his older brother (John Cusack).  The younger version of The Writer, Gordie predominantly spends his after school hours with a trio of boys who differ in personality but compare in their lack of self-confidence.  There's Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), a ne'er-do-well in the making whose family's reputation precedes him; Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman), the cocky but damaged son of an abuser; and Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell), a stocky jokester who hides his insecurities in humor, intentionally or otherwise.
	Their relationships are tested, though, when Vern informs them that he knows the whereabouts of a missing classmate, whose dead body lays twenty-some miles away after being struck by a train.  It's only a rumor - Vern's grapevine of information came from eavesdropping on his older brother - but all are curious, wanting to have an adventure, see what a dead body looks like, and maybe even become local heroes in the process.  Having terrible kinships with their families and therefore unworried about such mundanities as curfews, they start on their journey without hesitation.  And so begins a weekend's worth of adherence, revelatory exchanges, and golden moments of memory making; all will be changed, for better or worse, after their exploits come to a close.
	While its premise remains simple, "Stand By Me" is the effectual comedy-drama that it is because it's so rooted in accessibility.  Like Dreyfuss's wizened Writer, we can all agree that the friends we make during our youth are perhaps the best friends a person can have.  There's something markedly previous about that short period before puberty when nobody knows anything about life yet, when imaginations still have the capacity to run wild but are restrained by the figuring out of one's identity.  And "Stand By Me," capturing that susceptible time with singular clarity, is all the more impactful because of it.  The screenplay, co-written by Bruce A. Evans and Raynold Gideon, is remarkable in the way it so pitch-perfectly captures the way wily twelve-year-olds interact with one another, jokingly or emotionally.  Rob Reiner, an ace of the 1980s popcorn movie, directs with saccharine that feels completely appropriate rather than helplessly maudlin.
	But we, of course, take such a liking to "Stand By Me" as a result of its young performers, who inhabit their characters blisteringly and arrestingly.  O'Connell plays comic relief with naturally humorous flair, more in the spirit of a weathered comedian than a child actor.  Feldman is understatedly poignant as a kid who covers his neuroses with wit that seems to be increasingly lined in self-doubt the more we get to know him.  But especially stellar are Wheaton and Phoenix, whose characters are the closest of the bunch and whose performances are prodigiously stirring.  Whereas O'Connell and Feldman prove to be items (though delightful ones) of background, Wheaton and Phoenix are distinctly three-dimensional, both, on separate occasions, having breakdowns in the arms of the other and radiating sympathetic pain that we respond to with immediacy.  No one in its juvenile cast descends into camera mugging territory - all spitefully mature and all gifted actors, it's incredible that the age range of its central quartet only goes from twelve to fifteen.  Some adult professionals struggle to capture similar nuance.
	But that's why "Stand By Me" has lasted so long as a childhood classic for the people who grew up with it: it doesn't know what artificiality is, and doesn't know how to stay secure in the downfalls of redundant formula.  Its sincerity is everlasting, its emotional content invigoratingly unfeigned.  You'd have to be fitted with an ash covered heart to turn your back on its loving melancholy.

Our story involves four young boys on a trek to find the body of another young boy killed by a passing train. All four of the boys are played so authentically by their actors, but the true testament of their talents is the chemistry all four share with each other. It truly adds just that little something extra and makes the film just that much more believable.

While all four are great, the two that stand out most are our main character (Wil Wheaton as a kid, Richard Dreyfuss as an adult) and River Phoenix. The camaraderie between Wheaton and Phoenix seems the strongest of the lot, and both boys make the most of it. Both of them are given the film's two most touching moments: Phoenix when he's telling a story about stealing money and Wheaton when he talks about his dead brother. The sheer honesty of these two moments are just so powerful.

The other aspects of the film are solid. The screenplay is quite good and earned a well deserved Oscar nod, but this film belongs to our four young leads, who elevate the film to something outstanding.

Stand By Me is deservedly recognized as an all-time classic film, based on a story penned by one of the truly great writers of the past 100 years. A story about self-discovery and the effort to better understand life through the prism of death, Stand By Me is built around exceptionally well-written characters wonderfully brought to life through performances that might not be technically flawless, but that certainly benefit from an honesty and sense of camaraderie that make the story work. A "complete and total barf-o-rama" this movie is not; it's not only one of the best of the 1980s, but it's easily one of the finest coming-of-age films ever made.

First things first, and let's get this out of the way right out of the gate, but 15-year-old River Phoenix, assuming the film was shot in 1985 and then released in 1986, was an absolutely excellent actor.  I don't want to say that he was one of the elite actors of all time, but he was better than just about everyone BUT the truly elite by the age of FIFTEEN.  Think about that for a second.  FIFTEEN fucking years old and he's already better than a lot of people.  The film may certainly revolve around Wil Wheaton's character, but I'll be damned if River Phoenix isn't the heart and soul of this particular film.  I honestly didn't even find Wil Wheaton's character that interesting.  It's not that he doesn't have an interesting character arc, his parents ignored him after the death of his older brother, who was the apple of his parents' eyes and how he, in his own mind, believes that his parents would rather have him die instead of his older brother.  But, the fact of the matter is that without River's character for Gordie, Wil's character, to bounce that off from then the film simply wouldn't have worked on a deeper emotional level as it did.  It's not that Teddy or Vern, as characters, were useless, it's just that there's not the connection between either of them and Gordie as there is between Gordie and Chris.  So I think that, really, the entire film hinges on Chris being there and, ultimately, Gordie is inspired to write this story, as an adult, after hearing that Chris had been stabbed to death.  So Chris pretty much drives the narrative forward right from the beginning.  And I don't mean to say that Teddy or Vern don't comprise anything to the group.  Because, as a whole, these kids seemed like a great group of friends and I think the film definitely benefited from having both Vern and Teddy.  Particularly Vern, who added a comedic touch to the film.  But, as a whole, the casting is pretty much top-notch all around.  I think the film pretty much, perfectly, captures what it is like to be that age and the importance your friends are, particularly at that age, and how those bonds would change and mold you into the person you turn out to be as an adult.  Though it is also bittersweet in the sense that, even though it seemed to be like this group would be friends forever, how they eventually just drifted apart after their journey to see the dead body.  I think that's an universal theme, honestly.  Life takes you in different directions and maybe that means that you don't keep up with your friends quite like you used to in the past.  So that's quite poignant.  But, again, it also looks at the bonds you forged with these people and how important they truly are.  I think the film is incredibly well-written.  And the acting is excellent.  As mentioned, River Phoenix was just incredible here.  Jerry O'Connell and Corey Feldman are also really good here.  Honestly, I thought Wil Wheaton was the 'worst' of them all and he was still pretty good.  Very little in the way to complain about here, honestly.  This is a great movie from top-to-bottom.  It's funny and it's heartfelt.  The body, honestly, becomes irrelevant, even by the film's own implicit admission.  It's all about the journey for these boys and the journey is definitely worth taking, particularly if you haven't seen this film. Time for an adventure.  So this is about a band of four young boys in a small Oregon town.  When rumors start to circulate about a dead body of a missing classmate just outside of town, they decide to make it a day trip.  Rob Reiner really is one of my favorite sleeper directors; his name doesn't get brought up all that much when talking about the greats, but he has made a number of films that are bonafide classics (The Princess Bride, When Harry Met Sally...).  The films that he makes are all likable, but one thing I really appreciate is that he doesn't pad out his movies; he makes films as long as they need to be, so they have a tendency to run on the brisk side.  He's not afraid to make a movie 82 minutes long (This Is Spinal Tap) because he has a great understanding of the fact that it is better to leave the audience wanting more and not getting it, rather than risk getting tired of it.  Out of all the movies out there, this is probably the most quintessential coming of age film (when vindictively googling in "coming of age movies", this is second only behind The Breakfast Club).  You've got these boys on the brink of young adulthood, and they are getting pushed right over the line when they decide to make this trip.  That's also what helps to make this so memorable: this movie has a dark streak.  It's a very sordid story being told, and when you get to the epilogue, it gets downright harsh.  It makes it feel all the more realistic, though, and you 100% buy that these kids who think that swearing is cool are capable of being thrust into adulthood the moment they lay eyes on this dead body.  The adventure element to this makes it really easy to connect with.  While I would never personally go out on this trek, it is nevertheless fun to see these kids bro out with each other.  It's likable, and really captures what it's like to live in a small town where everybody knows your name.  All of these kids are types, but they are fully developed so they feel like real characters, and you can always identify with at least one of them.  Just as a side note, the visualization of the county fair was a little much, but it makes perfect sense because it's a kid telling the story.  This is great source material, and a wonderful adaptation.

I saw this movie for the first time today, and I absolutely fell in love with it.  I think that this movie shows such a boyish charm that not many movies convey.  The entire movie followed these four young boys as they went on a journey in the late 1950's.  

The story begins by introducing a man in his forties in his car reminiscing on when he was a boy and the adventure he had.  As the screen flashes to his memories, four young boys are introduced: the leader, Chris Chambers; the tough guy, Teddy Duchamp; the smart one, and Chris' best friend, Gordie Lachance; and the chubby goofball, Vern.  Vern overheard from his older brother of the location of a dead body of a boy around their age that the police have been looking for for a while.  The boys decide to embark on the journey for find the body and earn the fame from the town as heroes.  During this long hike into the woods, the boys grow and learn about each other and themselves quickly.  

After trespassing on the land of the towns crazy junkyard owner, a fight breaks out between him and Teddy, the tough-guy.  Teddy's day is known as being a drunk and has abused Teddy for most of his life; he even held Teddy's ear to the hot stove, scalding his ear and leaving Teddy's ear looking as if he were a professional boxer.  The junkyard man mocks Teddy's father and calls him bad names, however, Teddy defends his father, he retaliates by spitting out rude and hateful comments.  The boys eventually have to pull Teddy away from the man, and they continue on their way.  Teddy's willingness to fight an adult man shows his loyalty to his father, which explains who he later becomes.

Throughout the movie, Vern is seen as the happy-go-lucky one, he has a good head on his shoulders and is afraid to take big risks.  When the boys are getting close to the sight of the body, they could either take a shortcut through the woods, or keep following the train tracks.  All the boys begin running for the woods while Vern stays behind and shouts, "It's safer to follow the tracks!  We don't know what's in there!"  And one of the boys responds with, "Don't be a pussy!"  And Vern follows.  I believe that Vern's steady family results in him having a good, solid life, which results in who he grows up to be.

Chris Chambers, the leader of the group, is the strongest, mentally and physically.  His family is full of alcoholism and lawbreaking, he has always believed that his future is inevitable, and that he will end up exactly like his father and older brother.  He is known by the whole town for being the boy that stole some milk money once.  He explains later to Gordie that he tried to return the money, but the town still saw him as a no-good, money-stealing, mischief-maker.  During the entire movie Chris is seen as the peacemaker, he relaxes all the boys when their tempers get too high, and helps Gordie as he goes through his mental breakdowns, and Gordie helps Chris.  They make the perfect best friends because they can lean on each other when they need to, and help each other excel and become the best they can become.  It's Gordie's encouragement and Chris' caring words that push each other to grow into the men they are destined to.

Finally, Gordie, the smart and quiet one, and the narrator of the movie, has his struggles revealed to the audience early on, and they affect him for the duration of the movie, but the things that he goes through with his friends help him to grow and learn from his past problems.  I think that Gordie is the one that grows the most from the trip, and is no longer afraid and no longer second guesses himself.  With the help from his three best friends at that time, he becomes a great man.  

Overall, I think that this movie was very moving.  It made me wish I had a really tight knit group of friends that would go on adventures with me, and would want to watch me grow and help me better myself.  I think that this movie shows that we all have a good side, the side that everyone sees, and a bad side, that we never let anyone see.  But it takes an adventure, a campfire, some bullies, and amazing friends to expose that bad side, and change the bad parts of us, the parts we are afraid to put under a spotlight for fear of rejection, into parts we are proud of, parts we can grow from.

Yes, I know, string me up. I'm a child of the 80s who never saw Stand By Me until 2014! As a result I'm not sure it can possibly have the same impact on me it might have had if I saw it when I was closer to the age of the boys in the film. All I can say is that I found Stand By Me to be a fairly average coming-of-age drama. There are some moments that really shine, particularly when the boys start to open up with one another, but I don't know if those are enough to make this stand out from dozens of other films that tackle the same topic. I think it also helps if you connect with the kinds of activities these boys participated in. I never had friends who were into smoking, cursing, and gambling, so again it was one more point of disconnect for me. The story of the film isn't very deep. You have four boys, three of them with some very complex issues they are struggling with, and they decide to go on a long hike to locate the body of a missing teen. Child actors are always a little hit-or-miss, but I think they did fairly well with these 4. River Phoenix stands out as possibly the most talented, and I connected with his character more than the others because he had some serious demons he was struggling with.

Easily one of my favorite scenes of the movie is when Gordie tells one of his stories around the campfire, and then they show it all on screen as he describes it. This is so perfectly tuned to the kind of stuff boys at that age talk about that I had to laugh. I didn't know what to make of the scenes with the older gang of boys. Perhaps part of my issue with them was just the fact that I'm not a fan of Kiefer Sutherland, and picturing him as some murderous gang-banger kind of made me chuckle. Normally I'd call Richard Dreyfuss a win in any movie, but his voice-over did take me out of the film a couple of times. Of course voice-over was basically a prerequisite in coming-of-age films of the 80s so its not like they could have taken that out, his voice is just so distinctive that you can't really think "that's Wil Wheaton all grown up." Stand By Me is a prime example of its genre, and I'm sure at the time it was groundbreaking. Looking back at it now, I can recognize all the things that people might have enjoyed and connected with emotionally in 1986, I've just grown up too much since then...

But it would appear that I have seen one too many parodies of this story because the fact that we know what they are looking for makes the experience for them, and us, all the more different. You wouldn't think that you could get stressed out in a film like this but that train scene, boy, was that excellently crafted. I thought they could just lie down or step on the other rail if a train had have come but I had forgotten how big the train was. The lake scene was great as well, I think we could all work out that they were going to fall in but what happens later in that scene just looked painful. I thought the body would have been discovered there when they say that Vern had something on his neck but it wasn't and shouldn't they have all checked their underwear to see if they had anything? Ouch. Honestly though, the swearing didn't bother me, that's how real people talk and especially with the lack of parents around. No, what bothered me was the smoking. When it was introduced I thought that these weren't going to be likeable characters but that quickly changed, but I did notice how Gordie didn't smoke. Changed to make himself look better in his memoir? Or did he actually not smoke? Who knows? Although, they weren't smoking actual cigarettes either, thanks to Reiner. I did find it funny that there was a joke in there about how being a writer was stupid, given that Stephen King wrote the original story and it's a good job they didn't play around with that gun by pointing it at someone's head because that would have ended nastily for a supposedly empty gun and when the dog 'sick em up' I thought it sounded like 'stick em up' which would have worked in the '50s setting.

This cast is excellently chosen and it was even Jerry O'Connell's first film! The main 4 feel so real, they have all the wildly varying conversations a child would have at that time in their lives; and it isn't just Goofy that drove a car! You'd have thought that they would have been quiet when they thought there were about to be eaten by wolves but that's children! But that scene does end with a very powerful moment. These characters are excellently written and it is really great to see their journey. While I liked all the characters, and we know about all of them to some degree, although we know more about Gordie and Chris, for reasons the film gets into near the end, I couldn't really find myself liking Teddy all that much. While reminding me of a very young George McFly, I just found that he seemed to provoke everyone in the group and that he generally didn't have anything nice to say, especially when Gordie was telling them a story, (and when it ended the person in the story had a cherry in their ear, which I found funny and something that really fit in the story, although probably a coincidence). Again, I know they're young but you'd think that someone who got annoyed when that man in the junkyard called his dad a, 'loony, loony, loony', wouldn't call his friend a, 'pussy, pussy, pussy'. I thought he would be the one to sit next to Gordie when he was crying near the end just from the way that the conversation sounded but no, and it makes sense why it focuses on Gordie and Chris so much and the way this film ends really solidifies it and it hits hard. I thought I saw John Cusack in this film because of some images we see pretty quickly but a few seconds later, we do indeed see him and he turns out to be the only likeable supporting character. However, with this film I think it works for a couple reasons, one is that it might be from the perspective of what a child sees and it conveys the message about expressing oneself and that we really should listen to our children and support whatever their passion is, well, within reason. Still, I did find it a bit odd that random adults characters just go on rants for no real reason, like the guy in the shop and the junkyard, while the one in the junkyard had some reason to, he still felt a tad mean but the guy in the shop wasn't actually mean to Gordie, he just went on a rant just because. And, yeah, I guess someone could say that the fact that they have this story right before they go back to school was a bit of coincidence but that's going a bit far. But, hey, at least it isn't set in Maine, so that's something. Also, the same year this film came out, 'It' came out which is home to the horrible parents and one dimensional bullies as well. This film is absolutely timeless, well, besides the fact that you could get 4 cokes and some food for 2.50, but besides that, this film will live on forever. Based on the novel "The Body" by Stephen King, Stand by Me was one of those films that I had heard of but never used to have any real interest in it. I naturally assumed it would be good but never expected it to be anything special to myself personally. Oh, how wrong I was. As soon as it finished, I realised I had just witnessed one of the greatest films made.
Firstly the cast is nothing but perfect. Kiefer Sutherland as Ace Merrill excels at really making the audience hate him. You completely forget about his Jack Bauer alter-ego and can't help yourself from despising the character. Richard Dreyfuss bookends the film as an older version of the lead character and young John Cusack also pops in scenes which are sure to make you smile. But, it is the four young stars who really jump out at you. Will Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and an unrecognisable Jerry O'Connell are such naturals that you forget they are even acting. They are all full of talent at such a young age and are perfect for the roles. They blend together in a way that you would think they had been close friends for years. 
The film boasts a well written, easy to follow script with some really clever and humorous lines. Dialogue flows so perfectly that it feels like you are watching someone else's conversation. With scenery so beautiful, you at times wish you was on the journey with them.
No matter the age, you will relate to the characters featured. The interaction between the four boys and the message about friendship is so true to life, you will end up longing for those years once again.

One of those 80's films famed for its wealth of child actors and its classic soundtrack, possibly more so than its actual storyline and entertainment value. I went into this not fully knowing what to expect, but still came out a little disappointed as I had kind of bargained for something a little more gripping. In reality, it was a tale of four young boys who set off on an adventure to seek out the dead body of a local boy who has been reported missing by the police. Motivated by the fame and fortune that such a find could bring the lads set off along a railway line that will lead them to the whereabouts of the corpse. Although there are a few action sequences along the way, the bulk of the film is dominated by the interaction and relations between what are revealed to be four very different personalities, each suffering from mental trauma brought about through their family situations, and everyday life. The trek therefore provides a break from their problems, that is until a rival older gang seek to locate the body as well, and claim its find for their own benefit. Had this been four adults starring in this movie, it probably wouldn't have had the impact it has had, but you have to appreciate the talent that these four young stars possessed in making this a very emotional voyage. It doesn't have the imagination and fantasy of 'The Goonies' which also featured kids as its main cast, but to get across such a powerful childhood experience through four twelve year olds is pretty impressive and showcases more depth to their individual talents. It's not necessarily a must see again DVD, but it's a well produced film that should be remembered for its concept as well as its cast, and the late River Phoenix in particular.

Rob Reiner directs this coming-of-age drama based on the Stephen King novella, with a young cast including Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman (The Goonies), Jerry O'Connell and Kiefer Sutherland. 

A young group of kids set out on an adventure after gaining knowledge of a dead body out in the woods. In the group there is: Gordie (the writer), Chris (the leader), Teddy (the maniac), and Vern (the chubby one). 

They find out about the dead body from another group (a gang of older kids led by Kiefer Sutherland) after Vern overheard two of them talking. 

It is an adventure with a few laughs, some thrills and a lot of drama. 
 It is a nice childhood adventure that is told wonderfully through a soothing narrative, and the film isn't very long, so even if you don't like it - it isn't a waste of time. 

 It isn't my favourite movie based on a work of Stephen King's (but I love a lot of them, and this movie still wasn't near bad at all) or my favourite coming-of-age movie (it isn't The Breakfast Club of course) or my favourite adventure film either (it's not The Goonies), but it still is quite enjoyable, and has great acting and a good screenplay, it isn't boring, and it's still a story that works well in 2012. It's an overall good time.
